Skip navigation. Press enter to return to the slide.

search.slidetext: start course start course start course 1 trs system the biweekly employee

this training module focuses on the biweekly employee. the biweekly employee timesheet information policy & calculations accessing trs system interface entering time trs icons editing & submitting timesheets adding hours to the calendar entering repeated hours reporting on call hours formatting requirements reporting non-productive/ leave time types of non-productive /leave time administrative leave time alternate work schedules submitting a late timesheet recalling a timesheet errors on a timesheet trs help table of contents %menu.slidenumber% of %menu.totalslides% this training is about 20 minutes long

the biweekly employee non-exempt: eligible to claim overtime paid every two weeks: every other wednesday report all work hours and leave time required to report all work hours in accordance with federal fair labor standards act %menu.slidenumber% of %menu.totalslides%
timesheet information available on the first day of the pay period due on the last day of the pay period by 5pm %menu.slidenumber% of %menu.totalslides%

policy & calculations trs uses uc time and attendance policy to compute employee's total hours it automatically calculates any applicable overtime based on your employee %menu.slidenumber% of %menu.totalslides%
accessing the trs system username password %menu.slidenumber% of %menu.totalslides%

saved - hours have been entered and timesheet saved submitted to supervisor - timesheet has been submitted to the supervisor for approval recalled by employee - returns submitted timesheet to the employee returned by supervisor - supervisor has returned the timesheet back to the employee for edits submitted to dta - supervisor has approved the timesheet and submitted to dta submitted to ucpath - the dta has reviewed the timesheet and submitted it to ucpath for processing batch_locked - timesheet is locked while the system is processing it completed - trs processed the timesheet successfully without errors none - timesheet has not been opened, saved or submitted %menu.slidenumber% of %menu.totalslides%
trs icons view pdf view pdf view pdf view pdf view pdf view pdf %menu.slidenumber% of %menu.totalslides%

timesheet status codes saved - hours have been entered and timesheet saved submitted to supervisor - timesheet has been submitted to the supervisor for approval recalled by employee - returns submitted timesheet to the employee returned by supervisor - supervisor has returned the timesheet back to the employee for edits submitted to dta - supervisor has approved the timesheet and submitted to dta submitted to ucpath - the dta has reviewed the timesheet and submitted it to ucpath for processing batch_locked - timesheet is locked while the system is processing it completed - trs processed the timesheet successfully without errors none - timesheet has not been opened, saved or submitted x view status codes view status codes view status codes view status codes view status codes view status codes %menu.slidenumber% of %menu.totalslides%
adding hours to the calendar 3 47 %menu.slidenumber% of %menu.totalslides%
formatting time time in before time out %menu.slidenumber% of %menu.totalslides%
formatting time leave hour + work hour + call back hours < 24 hours %menu.slidenumber% of %menu.totalslides%
formatting time 12 8:08 12:00 1:00 5:00 trs will calculate 7.75 hours %menu.slidenumber% of %menu.totalslides%

repeated hours - use this entry to repeat hours across a selected range of dates. this can be used for any type of hours, including work and leave time. work hrs - use this entry to record actual hours worked vacation - use this entry to record vacation time taken sick - use this entry to record sick time taken comp time (used) - use this entry to record comp time taken jury - use this entry to record time off for jury duty military - use this entry to record military time off for duty lwop - use this entry to record leave without pay time off admin-to be determined by the service channel (paid time) erit- use to report time-related to employee reduction in time program fmla vac - use to report fmla vacation time (with pay) fmla sck (sick) - use to report fmla sick leave (with pay) fmla np (no pay) - use to report fmla time without pay fmla cmp (comp) - comp time (used) for fmla leave (used hours from employees comp blank in ucpath) call back - use to report call back hours after your scheduled work shift on call - used to report on call hours time on call-call back - used to report hours when called back into work while on call postdoc pto - use this entry to record paid time off taken postdoc sick - use this entry to record sick time taken emergency-to be determined by the service channel (paid time) *cat leave (catastrophe leave) - place holder at this time. phase 5 will either fix/remove *fmla cat (fmla catastrophe) - place holder at this time. phase 5 will either fix/remove %menu.slidenumber% of %menu.totalslides% types of non-productive/leave time use the scroll bar
alternate work schedule recurring work schedule 9/80 work schedule 4/80 work schedule temporary assignment %menu.slidenumber% of %menu.totalslides%
submitting a late timesheet trs payday calendar trs payday calendar trs payday calendar trs payday calendar trs payday calendar trs payday calendar %menu.slidenumber% of %menu.totalslides%

after submissions %menu.slidenumber% of %menu.totalslides% no action taken = you can recall your timesheet supervisor can return timesheet= employee receives email supervisor can emergency edit = employee receives email error on timesheet= employee contacts supervisor
trs help visit trs website view faqs timesheet deadlines %menu.slidenumber% of %menu.totalslides%

exit course exit course exit course restart course restart course restart course youve completed this course %menu.slidenumber% of %menu.totalslides% if you have questions or suggestions about this module, please drop us an email.

resource_data.description: Here are some useful links and documents:

resource.title: TRS Online Guide for Biweekly Employees

slidetranscripts.slidetranscript:
Welcome to the TRS Biweekly employee training module.
On this course, we will cover the topics displayed on this screen.
Please note that you can jump to a specific section of this module by clicking on the menu link at the top left of the screen to open then menu, and then selecting the slide you would like to view.
At times during this training,we will ask you to click on the 'next' arrow on the player to proceed.
Please note that we have added files relevant to this training under the Resources link.
Click next when you are ready to get started.

What is a biweekly employee? Biweekly employees are non exempt, meaning that they are eligible to claim overtime.
Biweekly employees are individuals who are paid every 2 weeks. Every other Wednesday a biweekly employee will receive a paycheck.
Work time must be entered on the time sheet in order to get paid in a timely fashion.
Delay in entering and submitting work time may result in delay of pay.
They are required to report all work hours in accordance with Federal Fair Labor Standards Act

Timesheets become available on the 1st day of the Pay Period (for example a timesheet for January 20 to February 2 is first available on January 20).

Biweekly Employee Timesheets are due on the LAST day of the Pay Period by 5pm (in other words, timesheet for January 20 to February 2 should be submitted by 5pm on February 2); the system email reminders are sent the day before the timesheet is due.

It is important to understand the purpose and restrictions on the account before you start reviewing the ledgers. Always make sure the charges posted to your account are allowable, reasonable and follow UC Davis policies and procedures, UCOP Policies, federal and state regulations.

For more information on accounts and funds visit the Understanding Your Accounts and Funds page, link provided on this screen and under the resources menu.

Please click next to continue.

All bi-weekly and monthly employees can access timesheets via a dedicated TRS webpage. To log in use the UC Net I D and password.

If you cannot log in using the UC log in details please speak to the supervisor or contact your local Information Technology support desk for further assistance.
After you login to your TRS application, and selected Employee from the initial screen,
you will land on the manage my time tab.

Let's take a look at the different areas of this tab.

Starting with the Timesheet Modifications: This section displays timesheets that the supervisor has modified (edited) for the employee.

The next area is dedicated to the Past Unsubmitted Timesheets, which displays any prior pay period timesheets that have been created by the employee but have not yet been submitted.

Note that the system will generate alerts to remind the employee of any overdue timesheets.
The Open Timesheets area displays the current pay period timesheets.
Use the Create Past Period Timesheets section to create a timesheet for a past period.
This section displays leave balances. Please note that the balances may not reflect late time adjustments, usage or accumulation since the last pay period.
And finally the Current Overtime compensation Method displays whether you are assigned to receive payment or compensation time.

Now let's take a look at the Review Past Timesheet tab.

The timesheet icon: Click the icon to open and view a past timesheet.
Click the workflow icon to see the workflow of a past timesheet.
The pay period column displays the pay period start and end dates.
The department job codes are displayed here.
The timesheet status column displays the timesheet status codes.

Once hours have been entered and submitted TRS automatically tracks the status of the timesheet.

Here are some of the most common codes.

After you become familiar with them, please click next to continue.

Use the "View Work schedule" tab to check your current work schedule.

TRS work schedules identify the days of the week and times of the day an employee is scheduled to work. A traditional full-time work schedule generally includes five eight-hour days worked Monday through Friday.

However, many employees hold part-time and, or alternative schedules such as a working a 4 10 schedule (10 hours a day, 4 days a week), or a 9 80 schedule (44 hours worked in the first week of the pay period, and 36 hours worked in the second week).


All of these types of schedules can be managed in the TRS work schedule tool.


Note: TRS work schedules are required for certain represented employee populations and also for 4/10 and 9/80 alternate work schedule assignments.

Let's stop here to talk about the icons on the TRS system interface.

TRS icons are widely displayed across TRS tabs and can be used to navigate the system. We have created a PDF with all the icons and their role in the system. You can view it now, or reach it later via the resources link at the top left of the screen.

Please click the next button to continue.

To edit and submit your timesheet, go to the "Manage My Time" tab.

You will see your Open Timesheets displayed.

Click the "view timesheet" icon to open it.

A timesheet calendar will appear where an employee can add work and leave hours.

Let's take a look at the different areas of this calendar and what they mean.

At the top of the calendar, you will see the reminder notification. It reminds the user when the tmesheet should be submitted to the supervisor.

Your personal information appears here.

Note the Name and ID number, Pay Period the begin and end dates of the pay period for the timesheet and the job assignment information, such as the department title code, name and timesheet identifier.

Observe that Current status of the timesheet is displayed here.

You can review the TRS Status Codes by clicking this button.

Click next when you are ready to continue.
The timesheet will display a work calendar for the two week pay period. Weekends and university holidays are shaded a different color.
The leave balances as indicated in UCPath are shown here.
The Timesheet Totals field displays productive, or work hours, and nonproductive hours, such as vacation, sick time, etc.

If setup, unique work schedules are displayed. Work schedules are required for employees who work a 9 80 or 4 40 Alternate Work Schedule and also for certain bargaining unit members , such as current state EX and SX.

This area displays any errors and warning messages that may occur when saving or submitting the timesheet.This area displays any errors and warning messages that may occur when saving or submitting the timesheet.
The timesheet comments field is optional. Comments entered here by an employee can be viewed by the supervisor and Department Time Administrator, the DTA, or payroll processor.
Users can save a timesheet to be submitted at a later date, or just submit to the supervisor when the timesheet is ready.

To enter the hours worked, select the relevant day, click Add and choose the Work Hours from the drop-down menu.

You will see different work hours types depending on your employment eligibility.

For example, the Add option can be used to report On-call and On Call Call Back hours, if applicable.
A pop-up window opens. Let's take look at the fields on this window.
Starting with the Time in, which is the starting time of a working shift.
Lunch out is the start time of a lunch break. Leave it blank if you didn't take a lunch break.
Lunch in is the time the lunch break ended. Leave it blank if you did not take a break.
Click the Add to Time Sheet button after entering your hours to add your hours to the calendar.
The new shift button adds a new row for you to record your hours.

At times, you may have to enter additional shifts for a days work.

This animation will illustrate how to enter your hours to the timesheet.

If an employee works the same shift every day and would like to report the same hours across a selected date range, then the Repeated Hours is a copy function that allows an employee to record repeated time for a selected date range. It can be used to report work hours (biweekly employees only) and nonproductive time off. For example, when an employee wishes to report two consecutive weeks, or 80 hours of vacation used in the pay period.

To avoid error messages please note the following format requirements for entering hours:

The hours must be entered in this format: hour hour minute minute

Please note that the hours cannot be negative.
Enter Time In hours before entering Time Out hours.

Time In of Shift 2 must be later than the Time Out of the previous shift.

Time Out hours must be entered for each Time In hours entered.

Time In and time out must be in chronological order.
They are allowed to cross mid-night.
The combination of hours reported must be under 24 hours for example, Leave hour + Work hour + Call back cannot exceed 24 hours.
You cannot enter lunch hours on a job if you do not clock into the job, for example, lunch start time cannot be at 7 am if your shift starts at 8 am.

Lunch Out must be entered before Lunch In and it must be on the same day.

Lunch In and Out hours cannot be reported after an employee has clocked out from a shift

Please note that UC Time and Attendance policy, TRS will compute the total hours for the day to the nearest quarter of the hour.

For example, if an employee:

Times In at 8:08 am

goes out for lunch at 12:00 PM

Returns from lunch at 1:00 PM

And goes home at 5:00 PM

TRS will calculate the total work hours as 7.75 hours.

TRS can be used to report non-productive/ leave time on the timesheet.

Let's stop here for a moment for you to become familiar with the codes available in TRS.

When you are ready to continue, please click the next button.

To report non-productive/leave hours:

Pick a day, click the Add and choose the appropriate leave type from a drop-down menu.

The selected leave type will be displayed on the relevant date. Enter the leave hours in the pop-up box.

If you need to delete the hours entered, click the trash can icon.

To avoid error messages please note the following format requirements when entering hours:
 Hours cannot be negative.
 Hours must be in quarter hour increments (for example: 8.0, 7.75, 6.5 etc.)
Click next to continue.

Sometimes an employee may take departmental approved administrative leave time away from the job to:
 telecommute or attend a seminar, conference, or class

TRS does not have entry codes for these types of administrative leave time, however, approved leave should be reported as work hours and indicated in the comments section, in the Timesheet Calendar View.

To report approved non-productive time off:

Add regular work time by selecting Work Hours from the Add dropdown menu in Timesheet Calendar View.

In the Timesheet Comments box indicate the type, date and time of the non-productive leave taken.

The Time Reporting System can currently accommodate these alternate work schedules.

Any of these alternate work schedules will be set up for you ahead of time. If you work an alternate schedule, and its not noted on your timesheet, contact your supervisor or the Department Time Administrator, ther DTA, for assistance.

If an employee has been approved to work a 9/80 Alternate Work Schedule (also known as flexible work schedule or AWS) the timesheet calendar view will display additional information below the timesheet. The 9/80 schedule is set up in TRS by a supervisor or DTA.

Employees designated to work a 9/80 AWS, usually work 44 hours in Week 1 and 36 hours with one day off in Week 2.

To help identify which work week an employee is working in for the 9/80 schedule, the date fields are color coded:

Week 1 Green

Week 2 Blue

If an employee is approved to work a 4/40 Alternate Work Schedule, also known as flexible work schedule or AWS, the timesheet calendar view will display additional information below the timesheet. The 4/40 schedule is set up in TRS by the supervisor or DTA.

Employees designated to work a 4 40 AWS, normally work 10 hours per day, 4 days a week.

If the employees title belongs to the Patient Care Technical Unit, or E X, or the Service Unit, or S X, they are subject to daily overtime rules. For those employees who are subject to daily overtime and normally work a fixed weekly work schedule, their timesheet calendar view will display additional information below the timesheet. The fixed schedule is set up in TRS by your supervisor or DTA.
The calendar on this screen shows an example of a Regular Work Schedule (first row) and a Temporary Assignment (second row).

At times an employee may wish to create a timesheet for a past pay period.

A past period timesheet can be created if an employee has missed a deadline and did not submit a timesheet on time. This can happen, for example, if they forgot to submit their timesheet by the deadline or their appointment.

Note: You can determine the pay period dates by referring to column 1 of the TRS Payday Calendar.

Please click next to continue.

Select a past pay period that you would like to create a timesheet for, or enter a date and click on the create button.

The calendar window opens up.

Click on the add button and select repeated hour to enter the work hours.

On Friday, this employee worked 7 hours, and took 1 hour of sick leave.

Now the calendar is ready to be submitted, so we click the submit to supervisor button.

At times, an employee may wish to make an update or an adjustment to the timesheet that has already been submitted to the supervisor. This can be achieved by requesting TRS to return the timesheet back to the employee in order to make adjustments.

There are 2 methods for recalling a timesheet:

From the Timesheet Calendar view - by selecting the Recall Timesheet button, which will appear once the timesheet has been submitted to the supervisor.

From the Enter Current Timesheet tab - by using the recall timesheet icon.

Note: The recall function can only be used if the timesheet has the status of Submitted to Supervisor. If the timesheet has been already edited or approved by the supervisor and submitted to the DTA for processing (status of Submitted to DTA), the employee must contact the supervisor or the DTA to have the timesheet returned to them.

Let's talk about what happens to the timesheet after you submit it.
You can recall your timesheet if the supervisor has not taken action on it.
Your supervisor can return timesheet for correction. The employee will receive a system email with the supervisor comments.
The supervisor can make edits in case of an emergency. The employee will be notified by email.
If there is an error on timesheet after it was approved, please contact your supervisor.

Contact your supervisor if you are unable to save or submit a timesheet due to errors that indicate that you don't have a supervisor set up in TRS, or no work schedule has been set up.

Your supervisor will contact your Department Time Administrator (DTA) who will make sure that you are correctly set up on TRS.

If you need help with the TRS system, please visit our website for guides, FAQ, best practices, scheduled automated emails, and system downtimes.

Please contact your supervisor if you have questions on how you should report your time in TRS.

You have completed this course. Click next to close it.
